entry.title: Why not just use X instead?
entry.content:
There are hundreds of static site generators. Why make yet another?

The short answer is that none of the static site generators I tested out did what I wanted out of the box (or required too much setup).

The most common issues were:

  • No support for relative links between Markdown files (that get translated to corresponding HTML files at build time)
  • No support for implicit categorization
  • No relative link checking at build time
  • Unintuitive template languages
  • Requiring installing new language runtimes

Here are some specific notes on popular SSGs:

Jekyll

Jekyll is probably the closest to what I was looking for, but I had no interest in setting up a Ruby environment or learning about the language (in case I needed to author my own plugins). I also didn't like the verbose syntax of the Liquid template language.

Hugo

Given that Hugo is broadly used and ships in a single binary, I thought I would end up using Hugo, but it was too general, and I wanted something with out-of-the-box support for a dev blog. Hugo's template language was also the most unintuitive template language I've ever seen.

Pelican

Pelican sounds like "Jekyll in Python", but I honestly didn't seriously consider it because I've had so many compatibility issues with Python in the past, that I generally try to avoid Python entirely. I realize I'm in the minority on this, but any language that practically requires virtual environments due to breaking changes seems too fragile for my delicate constitution.

Eleventy

I actually started out using Eleventy because it was very simple and easy to understand, but I ended up preferring Metalsmith (on which md2blog is now built) because Metalsmith was even simpler, to the point that I could easily understand everything it was doing, instead of having to guess.

Gatsby

I hate Gatsby, and pretty much any other "static" site generator that runs a bunch of client JavaScript to hopefully speed up subsequent page loads. Maybe I'm being unreasonable, but I want a static site generator to spit out HTML, not a web app.

Hexo

Hexo sounds like it might be a great static site generator, but by the time I gave it a serious look, I was already building on Eleventy (and later Metalsmith), so I didn't investigate Hexo further. I realize this isn't a great reason for not exploring Hexo, but it's the honest truth.

entry.title: How do I customize the theme?
entry.content:
Originally, I hadn't planned on making md2blog's theme customizable because theming would readily provide an irresistible distraction from authoring content (and eliminating such distractions is one of the main motivations for md2blog).

But in the end, I decided to make a concession to customization and add support for theming through the following four colors (specified in CSS color names like cyan or hex format, e.g. #ffee88):

  • Title (used for the site title)
  • Heading (used for top headings)
  • Link (used for links)
  • Comment (used only in code blocks)

All 4 colors are reused for syntax highlighting in code blocks.

To customize colors, use the colors.title, etc. properties in your site.json file (defaults values are shown):

{
    "title": "My blog",
// ...
    "colors": {
        "title": "#e6b95c",
        "heading": "#d97c57",
        "link": "#d97c57",
        "comment": "#7bbf56"
    }
}

I suggest serving the site locally with npx md2blog --serve while you play with the values and watch the page automatically reload in your browser.

entry.title: What are all the command line options?
entry.content:
$ npx md2blog --help

...

Options:
  -s, --serve            serve web site, with automatic reloading
  -c, --clean            clean output directory before processing
  -d, --drafts           include drafts in output
  -i, --input <dir>      input directory (default: "content")
  -o, --output <dir>     output directory (default: "out")
  --ignore-broken-links  don't check for broken relative links
  -h, --help             display help for command

entry.title: How do I add Google Analytics to my site?
entry.content:
md2blog has no built-in support for adding trackers to sites it generates, and there are no plans to add such support.

Frankly, as a reader, I'd prefer that you not add invasive tracking to your site. GoatCounter might be fine.
